channel.title: Info on Integrated Development Environments (IDEs)
channel.description:
So, I just installed Ubuntu on my PC due to it's ram failure and it's ability to only hold about 380mb of memory (rofl). So, since I needed an IDE, I thought I might as well put them to a bit of a test. Judging that only two IDEs are really used around here (NetBeans and Eclipse), I only tested them two.
[hr]
[b][size=14pt]NetBeans IDE 7.0[/size][/b] [i]Size: 68.4mb, approx. 200mb when installed.[/i] [i]Features: Base IDE, NetBeans SDK, Java SE[/i]
This thing loves to eat ram. Even on this very low ram'ed computer, it still seems to stay alive well, even when editing with it's visual editor. While editing using this, it spec'ed the following:
[i]CPU: 15% when idle, 45% upod editing Memory: 317.2MB (85%) Swap: 211.8MB (33.1%)[/i]
[hr]
[b][size=14pt]Eclipse Helios[/size][/b] [i]Size: 121.4mb, unknown size when installed.[/i] [i]Features: Base IDE, Little Bits of Goodies.[/i]
Seems to use quite a bit of CPU, but this seems to use a hell of a lot less RAM upon short periods of use, but this thing is a leaky bitch. Over time, it increases a huge amount. I'm not really taking that into account though. Seems to load pieces very quick.
[i]CPU: 61% when idle, about the same when editing Memory: 263.6MB (71%) Swap: 199MB (31%)[/i]
[hr]
In the end, neither wins (LOL), but basically, I recommend NetBeans if you're PC is relatively fast, but it still can be ran on some of those old assed computers. Eclipse seems to work best when you're on older computers, but I don't see why it would be bad on new ones too. Hopefully this is in the write section :|. If not...
[b]HoW do Is'd downrkld da stream writin n stuff. I cat find da client.jaba in da sources. halp. im noob at jaba.[/b]
Bye... and don't reply.

item.title: Info on Integrated Development Environments (IDEs)
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:12, topic:402180”][quote author=dain bramage link=topic=499232.msg3651375#msg3651375 date=1309754149]

forget ubuntu if you’re shitfucked for memory, try using a minimalist distro and a minimalist wm (forget full blown desktop environments) and vim with a few plugins. you should be fine then

Especially considering the default Ubuntu installation uses 400+ MB of RAM. Not everyone is comfortable enough to go through the install process of a better distro though.

I haven’t tried it, but ArchBang should help simplify the install of ArchLinux, and you get a nice WM out of it. Too bad I found out about it after I got my distro all set up >.>

LOL. You’re kidding, right? I had vista on a partion and it used less than 400mb of ram.
[/quote]

What optimizations have you done? My bare minimum Win7 uses 300mb idling, and I know Vista used more than that before all of its patches.

Why is MS notepad not on here

It’s like 2gb download and I cbfd.

If you’re on Ubuntu use gedit -.-

archlinux

++

i tried archbang but it never really grew on me, i guess i like building everything up by myself hehe

Is it somewhat minimal? I might try it next time, DSL sucks for pulling a large amount of packages >.>[/quote]

arch installs the base kernel, a few goodies and a package manager. that’s all.

Read full topic

forget ubuntu if you’re shitfucked for memory, try using a minimalist distro and a minimalist wm (forget full blown desktop environments) and vim with a few plugins. you should be fine then

Especially considering the default Ubuntu installation uses 400+ MB of RAM. Not everyone is comfortable enough to go through the install process of a better distro though.

I haven’t tried it, but ArchBang should help simplify the install of ArchLinux, and you get a nice WM out of it. Too bad I found out about it after I got my distro all set up >.>
[/quote]
LOL. You’re kidding, right? I had vista on a partion and it used less than 400mb of ram.[/quote]

What optimizations have you done? My bare minimum Win7 uses 300mb idling, and I know Vista used more than that before all of its patches.

[quote=“dain bramage, post:11, topic:402180”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=499232.msg3651388#msg3651388 date=1309755448]
Why is MS notepad not on here
[/quote]
It’s like 2gb download and I cbfd.[/quote]

If you’re on Ubuntu use gedit -.-

SETO:

archlinux

++

_s:

i tried archbang but it never really grew on me, i guess i like building everything up by myself hehe

Is it somewhat minimal? I might try it next time, DSL sucks for pulling a large amount of packages >.>

Read full topic

item.title: Info on Integrated Development Environments (IDEs)
item.dc:creator: @dain_bramage dain bramage
item.description:
@dain_bramage wrote:

So, I just installed Ubuntu on my PC due to it’s ram failure and it’s ability to only hold about 380mb of memory (rofl). So, since I needed an IDE, I thought I might as well put them to a bit of a test. Judging that only two IDEs are really used around here (NetBeans and Eclipse), I only tested them two.

[hr]

[size=14pt]NetBeans IDE 7.0[/size]
Size: 68.4mb, approx. 200mb when installed.
Features: Base IDE, NetBeans SDK, Java SE

This thing loves to eat ram. Even on this very low ram’ed computer, it still seems to stay alive well, even when editing with it’s visual editor. While editing using this, it spec’ed the following:

CPU: 15% when idle, 45% upod editing
Memory: 317.2MB (85%)
Swap: 211.8MB (33.1%)

[hr]

[size=14pt]Eclipse Helios[/size]
Size: 121.4mb, unknown size when installed.
Features: Base IDE, Little Bits of Goodies.

Seems to use quite a bit of CPU, but this seems to use a hell of a lot less RAM upon short periods of use, but this thing is a leaky bitch. Over time, it increases a huge amount. I’m not really taking that into account though. Seems to load pieces very quick.

CPU: 61% when idle, about the same when editing
Memory: 263.6MB (71%)
Swap: 199MB (31%)

[hr]

In the end, neither wins (LOL), but basically, I recommend NetBeans if you’re PC is relatively fast, but it still can be ran on some of those old assed computers. Eclipse seems to work best when you’re on older computers, but I don’t see why it would be bad on new ones too. Hopefully this is in the write section :|. If not…
